'''International Women's Day''' ('''IWD''') is a [[holiday]] celebrated annually on March 8 as a focal point in the [[women's rights|women's rights movement]]. IWD gives focus to issues such as [[gender equality]], [[reproductive rights]], and [[Violence against women|violence and abuse against women]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=About International Women's Day|url=https://www.internationalwomensday.com/about|access-date=March 8, 2021|website=International Women's Day|language=en|archive-date=June 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603171245/https://www.internationalwomensday.com/About|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="UN">{{Cite web|title=International Women's Day|url=https://www.un.org/en/observances/womens-day|access-date=March 8, 2021|website=United Nations|language=en|archive-date=March 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210307203632/https://www.un.org/en/observances/womens-day|url-status=live}}</ref> Spurred by the [[Women's suffrage|universal female suffrage]] movement, IWD originated from [[labour movement|labor movements]] in North America and Europe during the early 20th century.<ref>{{Cite web|title=History of International Women's Day|url=https://www.internationalwomensday.com/Activity/15586/The-history-of-IWD|access-date=March 8, 2021|website=International Women's Day|language=en|archive-date=March 7, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210307202122/https://www.internationalwomensday.com/Activity/15586/The-history-of-IWD|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Nations">{{Cite web|last=Nations|first=United|title=Background {{!}} International Women's Day|url=https://www.un.org/en/observances/womens-day/background|access-date=March 8, 2021|website=United Nations|language=en|archive-date=March 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200308132802/https://www.un.org/en/observances/womens-day/background|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Stories of women's activism|url=https://nzhistory.govt.nz/culture/suffrage125/three-waves-of-womens-activism|access-date=February 18, 2022|website=nzhistory.govt.nz|language=en|archive-date=February 18, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220218003206/https://nzhistory.govt.nz/culture/suffrage125/three-waves-of-womens-activism|url-status=live}}</ref> [[File:Goma, North-Kivu, DR Congo - Female officers of the FARDC and MONUSCO - International Day of Women's Rights.jpg|thumb|Female soldiers from Peru, Egypt, India and other countries celebrate International Women's Day.]] [[File:703A0789.jpg|thumb|Female soldiers from Peru, Egypt, India and other countries celebrate International Women's Day.]]
The earliest version reported was a "[[National Woman's Day|Woman's Day]]" organized by the [[Socialist Party of America]] in [[New York City]] on February 28, 1909. This inspired German delegates at the [[International Socialist Women's Conferences|1910 International Socialist Women's Conference]] in [[Copenhagen]] to propose "a special Women's Day" be organized annually, albeit with no set date;<ref name="ICSW">{{Cite web|title="International Socialist Congress, 1910; Second International Conference of Socialist Women|url=https://archive.org/details/InternationalSocialistCongress1910SecondInternationalConferenceOf/page/n21/mode/2up|page=21|access-date=March 7, 2020}}</ref> the following year saw the first demonstrations and commemorations of International Women's Day across Europe. After the [[Russian Revolution]] in 1917, IWD was made a national [[holiday]] on March 8;<ref name=Pruitt>{{Cite web |last=Pruitt |first=Sarah |date=2023-09-13 |title=The Surprising History of International Women's Day |url=https://www.history.com/news/the-surprising-history-of-international-womens-day |access-date=2023-11-02 |website=[[History (American TV network)|HISTORY]] |language=en}}</ref> it was subsequently celebrated on that date by the [[socialist movement]] and [[communist countries]]. The holiday became a mainstream global holiday following its promotion by the [[United Nations]] in 1977.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.un.org/en/observances/womens-day/background|title=International Women's Day, 8 March|website=United Nations|language=en|access-date=March 7, 2020|archive-date=March 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200308132802/http://www.un.org/en/observances/womens-day/background|url-status=live}}</ref>
International Women's Day is a public holiday in several countries. The UN observes the holiday in connection with a particular issue, campaign, or theme in women's rights.<ref name="Nations"/>
==History== ===Origins=== [[File:Zetkin luxemburg1910.jpg|thumb|left|[[Clara Zetkin]] (left) and [[Rosa Luxemburg]] (right) in January 1910]] The earliest reported Women's Day event, called "[[National Woman's Day|Woman's Day]]",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://iwd.uchicago.edu/page/international-womens-day-history#1909%20The%20First%20National%20Woman's%20Day%20in%20the%20US|title=International Women's Day History {{!}} International Women's Day {{!}} The University of Chicago|website=iwd.uchicago.edu|language=en|access-date=April 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170408081654/https://iwd.uchicago.edu/page/international-womens-day-history#1909%20The%20First%20National%20Woman's%20Day%20in%20the%20US|archive-date=April 8, 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> was held on February 28, 1909, in New York City. It was organized by the [[Socialist Party of America]]<ref name="unevents">{{cite web|title=United Nations page on the background of the IWD|url=https://www.un.org/en/observances/womens-day/background|url-status=live|access-date=March 8, 2012|publisher=Un.org|archive-date=March 8, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200308132802/https://www.un.org/en/observances/womens-day/background}}</ref> at the suggestion of activist [[Theresa Malkiel]].<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Sally M. |last1=Miller |title=From Sweatshop Worker to Labor Leader: Theresa Malkiel, A Case Study |journal=American Jewish History |volume=68 |issue=2 |date=December 1978 |page=197 |jstor=23881894}}</ref> There have been claims that the day was commemorating a protest by women garment workers in New York on March 8, 1857, but researchers have described this as a myth.<ref name="kaplan" /><ref name="Françoise Picq 1982">{{cite journal |first1=Liliane |last1=Kandel |first2=Françoise |last2=Picq |url=http://www.archivesdufeminisme.fr/article.php3?id_article=80 |title=Le Mythe des origines à propos de la journée internationale des femmes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927183523/http://www.archivesdufeminisme.fr/article.php3?id_article=80 |archive-date=September 27, 2013 |journal=La Revue d'en face |volume=12 |year=1982 |pages=67–80 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |first=Angela Howard |last=Zophy |title=Handbook of American Women's History |publisher=Garland |year=1991 |page=187 |isbn=0-8240-8744-5 }}</ref>
In August 1910, an [[International Socialist Women's Conferences#Copenhagen 1910|International Socialist Women's Conference]] was organized ahead of the general meeting of the Socialist [[Second International]] in Copenhagen, Denmark.<ref name="ruthchild 2012">Rochelle Goldberg Ruthchild, "From West to East: International Women's Day, the First Decade", ''Aspasia: The International Yearbook of Central, Eastern, and Southeastern European Women's and Gender History'', vol. 6 (2012): 1–24.</ref> Inspired in part by the American socialists, German delegates [[Clara Zetkin]], [[Käte Duncker]], [[Paula Thiede]], and others proposed the establishment of an annual "Women's Day", although no date was specified.<ref name="ICSW" /><ref name="kaplan">{{cite journal |first=Temma |last=Kaplan |title=On the Socialist Origins of International Women's Day |journal=Feminist Studies |volume=11 |issue=1 |year=1985 |pages=163–171 |jstor=3180144|doi=10.2307/3180144 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= History of International Women's Day |url= https://www.un.org/womenwatch/feature/iwd/history.html |publisher= United Nations |access-date= May 26, 2012 |archive-date= July 3, 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190703185713/https://www.un.org/womenwatch/feature/iwd/history.html |url-status= live }}</ref> The 100 delegates, representing 17 countries, agreed with the idea as a strategy to promote equal rights, including [[suffrage|women's suffrage]].<ref name="iwd">{{cite web |url=http://www.internationalwomensday.com/About |title=About International Women's Day |publisher=Internationalwomensday.com |date=March 8, 1917 |access-date=February 26, 2016 |archive-date=September 16, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190916195847/https://www.internationalwomensday.com/About |url-status=live }}</ref>
The following year, on March 19, 1911, the first International Women's Day was marked by over a million people in Austria-Hungary, Denmark, Germany, and Switzerland.<ref name="unevents" /> In Austria-Hungary alone, there were 300 demonstrations,<ref name="kaplan" /> with women parading on the [[Ringstrasse]] in Vienna, carrying banners honoring the martyrs of the [[Paris Commune]].<ref name="kaplan" /> Across Europe, women demanded the [[right to vote]] and to hold public office, and protested against employment sex discrimination.<ref name="UN" />
IWD initially had no set date, though it was generally celebrated in late February or early March. Americans continued to observe "[[National Woman's Day|Woman's Day]]" on the last Sunday in February, while Russia observed International Women's Day for the first time in 1913, on the last Saturday in February (albeit based on the [[Julian calendar]], as in the Gregorian calendar, the date was March 8).<ref name="mmf1" /> In 1914, International Women's Day was held on March 8 for the first time in Germany, possibly because that date was a Sunday.<ref name="mmf1">{{cite web |url=http://www.mmf2010.info/our-action/le-8-mars-2013-journee-internationale-des-femmes-a-la-recherche-de-la-memoire-perdue |title=8th of March – International woman's day: in search of lost memory |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110313064904/http://www.mmf2010.info/our-action/le-8-mars-2013-journee-internationale-des-femmes-a-la-recherche-de-la-memoire-perdue |archive-date=March 13, 2011|url-status=dead |access-date=March 14, 2014}}</ref> As elsewhere, Germany's observance was dedicated to women's right to vote, which German women did not win until 1918.<ref name="mmf1" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ipu.org/wmn-e/suffrage.htm |title=Women's Suffrage |publisher=Inter-Parliamentary Union |access-date=January 26, 2014 |archive-date=August 7, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807104506/http://www.ipu.org/wmn-e/suffrage.htm |url-status=live }}</ref> Concurrently, there was a march in London in support of women's suffrage, during which [[Sylvia Pankhurst]] was arrested in front of [[Charing Cross]] station on her way to speak in [[Trafalgar Square]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Suffragist Disorders|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/archive/article/1914-03-09/5/1.html#start%3D1785-01-01%26end%3D1985-12-31%26terms%3D%22Sylvia%20Pankhurst%22%20arrested%26back%3D/tto/archive/find/%252522Sylvia+Pankhurst%252522+arrested/w:1785-01-01%7E1985-12-31/o:date/4%26prev%3D/tto/archive/frame/goto/%252522Sylvia+Pankhurst%252522+arrested/w:1785-01-01%7E1985-12-31/o:date/32%26next%3D/tto/archive/frame/goto/%252522Sylvia+Pankhurst%252522+arrested/w:1785-01-01%7E1985-12-31/o:date/34|access-date=May 9, 2014|newspaper=The Times|date=March 9, 1914|archive-date=March 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220302155147/https://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/archive/article/1914-03-09/5/1.html#start%3D1785-01-01%26end%3D1985-12-31%26terms%3D%22Sylvia%20Pankhurst%22%20arrested%26back%3D/tto/archive/find/%252522Sylvia+Pankhurst%252522+arrested/w:1785-01-01%7E1985-12-31/o:date/4%26prev%3D/tto/archive/frame/goto/%252522Sylvia+Pankhurst%252522+arrested/w:1785-01-01%7E1985-12-31/o:date/32%26next%3D/tto/archive/frame/goto/%252522Sylvia+Pankhurst%252522+arrested/w:1785-01-01%7E1985-12-31/o:date/34|url-status=live}}</ref>
===The Russian Revolution and Communist countries=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horisontal | image1 = The Soviet Union 1949 CPA 1368 stamp (International Women's Day, March 8. Political leadership).jpg | image2 = 1947 CPA 1140 cancelled.jpg | footer = Soviet postage stamps }}
On March 8, 1917, in [[Petrograd]] (February 23, 1917, on the [[Julian calendar]]), women textile workers began a demonstration that eventually engulfed the whole city, demanding "Bread and Peace"—an end to World War I, to food shortages, and to [[Tsarist autocracy|Tsarism]].<ref name="mmf1" /> This marked the beginning of the [[February Revolution]], which alongside the [[October Revolution]], made up the [[Russian Revolution]].<ref name="UN" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://ria.ru/revolution_postup/20170306/1489217048.html|title=February Revolution|date=March 6, 2017|publisher=[[RIA Novosti]]|access-date=March 7, 2017|archive-date=March 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220302154812/https://ria.ru/20170306/1489217048.html|url-status=live}}</ref> Revolutionary leader [[Leon Trotsky]] wrote, "23 February (8th March) was International Woman's Day and meetings and actions were foreseen. But we did not imagine that this 'Women's Day' would inaugurate the revolution. Revolutionary actions were foreseen but without a date. But in the morning, despite the orders to the contrary, textile workers left their work in several factories and sent delegates to ask for the support of the strike… which led to mass strike... all went out into the streets."<ref name="mmf1" /> Seven days later, Tsar [[Nicholas II]] abdicated, and the [[Russian Provisional Government|provisional Government]] granted women the right to vote.<ref name="unevents" />
After the Russian Revolution, [[Bolshevik]]s began to celebrate the International Women's Day on 8 March as it marked the beginning of revolutionary changes in 1917 in Russia. However, it was not officially declared as such for some time. For example, the first congress of the newly founded Communist International could only adopt a very brief "Resolution on the Role of Working Women" submitted by [[Alexandra Kollontai]] on 6 March 1919, which made no mention of 8 March or IWD. The second congress convened next year couldn't even find time for it, although it began holding an "International Conference of Communist Women" (organized by a newly created "International Secretariat on Work Amongst Women") under its auspices. It was only during the third world congress of Communist International in 1921 that an important document titled "Methods and Forms of Work Among Communist Party Women: Theses" was adopted as a result of the work of the Second International Conference of Communist Women held in parallel to this congress. The theses mentioned "organizing an annual International Working Women's Day" among the tasks of central women's department of communist parties.<ref>{{cite book |title=Theses, Resolutions and Manifestos of the First Four Congresses of the Third International |editor=Alan Adler |translator=Alix Holt, Barbara Holland |publisher=Ink Links |year=1980 |pages=46, 177, 210–229, 325–26 |isbn=0-906133-12-2 }}</ref>
After its adoption in [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Soviet Russia]], IWD was predominantly celebrated in communist countries and by the communist movement worldwide. In the [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic]], huge Soviet-style celebrations were held annually.<ref name="Kapusta‐Pofahl">{{cite web |url=https://scholarworks.iu.edu/journals/index.php/aeer/article/viewFile/1284/1356 |title=Reinstating International Women's Day in the Czech Republic: Feminism, Politics and the Specter of Communism |author=Karen Kapusta-Pofahl |publisher=Washburn University |access-date=February 28, 2016 |archive-date=March 5, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170305030020/https://scholarworks.iu.edu/journals/index.php/aeer/article/viewFile/1284/1356 |url-status=live }}</ref> Chinese communists observed the holiday beginning in 1922,<ref name="kaplan" /> though it soon gained traction across the [[political spectrum]]. In 1927, [[Guangzhou]] saw a march of 25,000 women and male supporters, including representatives of the [[Kuomintang]], the [[YWCA]], and labor organizations.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Yau Tsit Law|title=International Women's Day in Canton March 8, 1927|journal=News Bulletin (Institute of Pacific Relations)|date=June–July 1927}}</ref> After the founding of the [[People's Republic of China]] on October 1, 1949, the State Council proclaimed on December 23 that March 8 would be made an official holiday, with women given a half-day off.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anniversaries of important events|url=http://www.gov.cn/english/2005-08/10/content_28291.htm|website=China Factfile|publisher=Chinese Government|access-date=August 28, 2011|archive-date=September 13, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190913161251/http://www.gov.cn/english/2005-08/10/content_28291.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref>
[[Hujum]] ({{lang-rus|Худжум|Khudzhum|xʊd͡ʐʐʊm}}; in [[Turkic languages]], ''storming'' or ''assault'', from {{langx|ar|هجوم}}) was a series of policies and actions taken by the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]], initiated by [[Joseph Stalin]] on International Women's Day in 1927, to remove all manifestations of [[gender inequality]], especially the systems of female [[veil]]ing and seclusion practiced in [[Central Asia]].<ref>Northrop, Douglas (2001a). "Subaltern dialogues: subversion and resistance in Soviet Uzbek family law". Slavic Review. 60 (1): 115–139. doi:10.2307/2697646. JSTOR 2697646. S2CID 147540996, p. 115.</ref><ref>The Bolsheviks and Islam, International Socialism – Issue: 110</ref> On May 8, 1965, the [[Presidium of the Supreme Soviet]] issued a decree to make March 8, International Women’s Day, a non-working public holiday ‘in honor of the outstanding achievements of the Soviet women in building communism, defending the motherland during the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Great Patriotic War]], their heroism and selflessness both at the front and at home, and for their great contribution to the strengthening of friendship among peoples, and to the struggle for peace’.<ref>{{Cite web|title=International Women's Day |url=https://www.prlib.ru/en/history/619080 |access-date=2024-08-16 }}</ref> [[File:Hujum.png|150px|thumbnail|left|A [[:ru:Чачван|veil]]-burning ceremony in [[Andijan]] on International Women's Day in 1927.]]
===Other countries, 1920s to 1960s=== In 1928, Australia first observed International Women’s Day, a rally in [[The Domain, Sydney|Sydney’s Domain]] organized by the Militant Women's Group of the Communist Party.<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sydney.edu.au/arts/news-and-events/news/2019/03/08/title-international-womens-day-origins-past-and-present.html|title=International Women's Day: origins, past and present|website=The University of Sydney}}</ref> At that rally, held on March 25, women rallied in support of fully paid annual holidays, equal pay for equal work, female store clerks having eight-hour days, an end to [[piece work]], and a basic wage for those without employment.<ref name="auto3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/content/radical-history-international-women%E2%80%99s-day|title=The radical history of International Women's Day|first=Kathy|last=Fairfax|date=March 3, 2017|website=Green Left}}</ref> Later, the first International Women's Day marches happened in Sydney and Melbourne, in 1931. The Sydney march featured approximately sixty women leading three hundred to five hundred marchers. The Melbourne march consisted of fifty women leading one hundred and fifty marchers, with a banner in front stating, "Long Live International Women's Day". In 1938, the first major International Women’s Day meeting in Perth was held; in attendance were women from the Association of University Women, Jewish Women, [[Mothers Union]], [[Movement Against War and Fascism]], [[National Council of Women of Australia|National Council of Women]], Spanish Relief Committee, [[Women's Christian Temperance Union]], [[Women's International League for Peace and Freedom]], Women's Section of [[National Party of Australia – Queensland|Primary Producers]], [[Women's Service Guilds]], Young Labor League, and [[YWCA]].<ref name="auto3"/>
Communist leader [[Dolores Ibárruri]] led a women's march in Madrid in 1936 on the eve of the [[Spanish Civil War]].<ref name="kaplan" />
The [[Congress of American Women]] was an American [[women's rights]] organization founded in New York on International Women's Day in 1946, following the 1945 founding conference of the [[Women's International Democratic Federation]] in Paris, to which it affiliated. Its primary organizer was [[Elinor S. Gimbel]] (wife of Louis S. Gimbel, Jr., grandson of [[Adam Gimbel]] of [[Gimbels]] department store.<ref> {{cite web | title = Louis S. Gimbel, Jr. | publisher = Arlington National Cemetery | url = http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/lsgimbel.htm | date = | access-date = 26 March 2016}}</ref>) In 1948 the organization was attacked as a communist front organization by the [[House Un-American Activities Committee]] and was forced to register as a "subversive" organization. The organization was finally dissolved in 1950. The congress was an official US branch of the [[Women's International Democratic Federation]], which though an antifascist organization was pro-Soviet.<ref name=":congress0">{{cite book |last=Gore |first=Dayo F. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-3YVCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA59 |title=Radicalism at the Crossroads: African American Women Activists in the Cold War |publisher=[[NYU Press]] |year=2012 |isbn=978-0-8147-7011-5 |location=New York City}}</ref> The organization supported progressive policies giving women full rights and equality both in the home and economically. They supported labor organizing and civil rights and were against anticommunist attacks on liberals.{{sfn|Gore|2012|p=59}} Though many members were communists or part of the [[popular front]], membership in the organization included a broad mix of liberal, middle-class women.<ref name=":congress0" />
In 1956 in Singapore, [[Chan Choy Siong]], along with Ho Puay Choo and Oh Siew Chen, created the Women's League within the [[People's Action Party]], and that year, to recognize International Women’s Day, the League organized four rallies across Singapore, which attracted more than 2,000 people in total.<ref name=":Singapore2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=otq-cacQxZ0C&q=%22Chan+Choy+Siong%22&pg=PA36|title=In the Mood for Cheongsam: A Social History, 1920s – Present|last=Lee|first=Chor Lin|date=2012|publisher=Editions Didier Millet|isbn=9789814260923|pages=36, 38|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.swhf.sg/milestones/|title=MILESTONES|website=Singapore Women's Hall of Fame}}</ref>
In 1958, [[Christina F. Lewis]] organized the first International Women's Day observance in [[Trinidad and Tobago]].<ref>Hosein, Gabrielle (12 March 2014). "Our feminist legacy intact". The Trinidad and Tobago Guardian. Port of Spain, Trinidad. Archived from the original on 10 February 2019. Retrieved 10 February 2019.</ref>
In 1965, [[Anahita Ratebzad]] along with other members of the [[Democratic Organisation of Afghan Women]] (DOAW) organized a protest march on March 8 in [[Kabul]], which was the first observance of International Women's Day in Afghanistan.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.internationalen.se/2010/03/kvinnorna-i-afghanistan-tog-av-sig-slojan-redan-1959/|title = Kvinnorna i Afghanistan tog av sig slöjan redan 1959 {{!}} Internationalen|website = www.internationalen.se|access-date = 2016-03-08|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160308211851/http://www.internationalen.se/2010/03/kvinnorna-i-afghanistan-tog-av-sig-slojan-redan-1959/|archive-date = 2016-03-08|url-status = dead}}</ref>
===Second–wave feminism=== [[File: NSW Builders Labourers march on IWD 1975.jpg|thumb|left|Female members of the Australian [[Builders Labourers Federation]] march on International Women's Day 1975 in Sydney]] IWD remained predominantly a communist holiday until circa 1967 when it was taken up by [[Second-wave feminism|second-wave feminists]].<ref name="kaplan" /> The day re-emerged as a day of activism, and is sometimes known in Europe as the "Women's International Day of Struggle". In the 1970s and 1980s, women's groups were joined by leftists and labor organizations in calling for equal pay, equal economic opportunity, equal legal rights, [[reproductive rights]], subsidized child care, and the prevention of violence against women.<ref name="Søland">{{cite web|url=http://origins.osu.edu/connecting-history/international-womens-day|title=International Women's Day|first=Birgitte|last=Søland|publisher=Origins|date=March 4, 2019|access-date=March 10, 2019|archive-date=March 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220302155203/https://origins.osu.edu/connecting-history/international-womens-day|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wbur.org/news/2017/01/20/boston-womens-march-history|title=Ahead Of The Boston Women's March, A Look Back 47 Years Ago|first=Elizabeth|last=Gillis|publisher=WBUR|date=January 20, 2017|access-date=July 22, 2019|archive-date=March 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220302155146/https://www.wbur.org/news/2017/01/20/boston-womens-march-history|url-status=live}}</ref>
International Women's Day had been largely forgotten in the United States by the late 1960s, before an activist called [[Laura X]] organized a march in Berkeley, California, on International Women’s Day in 1969.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bernikow |first=Louise |date=2005-03-02 |title=The Birth of Women's History Month |url=https://womensenews.org/2005/03/the-birth-womens-history-month/ |access-date=2023-03-01 |website=Women's eNews |language=en-US}}</ref> The march led to the creation of The Women’s History Research Center, a central archive of the women’s movement from 1968 to 1974.<ref>{{Cite web |title=1970: Reviving the fighting spirit of Int'l Women's Day |url=https://www.workers.org/2005/us/womens-day-0303/ |access-date=2023-03-01 |website=www.workers.org}}</ref> Laura X also thought it unfair for half the human race, meaning women, to have only one day a year and called for National [[Women's History Month]] to be built around International Women’s Day.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Anniversary of Women's History Library/NCMDR |url=https://ncmdr.org/anniv.html |access-date=2023-03-01 |website=ncmdr.org}}</ref> The Women’s History Research Center collected nearly one million documents on microfilm, and provided resources and records of the women’s liberation movement that are now available through the National Women’s History Alliance, which carried on their ideas, including successfully petitioning Congress to declare March as Women’s History Month.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Women's History in the Digital World 2015 – Ken Wachsberger's Blog |url=https://kenwachsberger.wordpress.com/tag/womens-history-in-the-digital-world-2015/ |access-date=2023-03-01 |website=Ken Wachsberger's Blog |language=en}}</ref>
In Australia, 1972 was when large IWD marches began.<ref name="auto2"/>
Announced in 1978 on International Women’s Day, the [[Women’s Work Committee]] in Palestine came to represent an association willing to develop a strategy to combine national liberation and women's liberation. The founders of the committee were disappointed in the actions of previous charitable societies as they failed to educate the general population; to rectify this issue, they launched programs promoting literacy, health education, and classes teaching embroidery. Further aiding those of a working-class background, they started daycare centers to allow them to continue working as their children were being cared for.<ref name=":8">Hiltermann, Joost R. “The Women’s Movement during the Uprising.” ''Journal of Palestine Studies'' 20, no. 3 (1991)</ref>
On [[1979 International Women's Day protests in Tehran|International Women's Day in 1979]], a women's march took place in [[Tehran]] in [[Iran]]. The march was originally intended to celebrate International Women's Day, but transformed into massive protests against the changes taking place in women's rights during the [[Iranian revolution]], specifically the introduction of mandatory [[hijab]] (veiling), which had been announced the day before. The protests lasted for six days, from 8 March to 14 March 1979, with thousands of women participating. The protests resulted in a temporary retraction of the decree of mandatory veiling. When the left and the liberals were eliminated, and the conservatives secured sole control, however, veiling was enforced on all women.<ref name="Iran">John Foran, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=2Z2FAgAAQBAJ&dq=1979+iran+hijab+protest&pg=PA144 Theorizing Revolutions]''</ref>
[[File:María Elena Oddone en 1984.jpg|left|thumb|[[María Elena Oddone]] holding a banner, on International Women's Day in 1984 in Argentina. The banner says "No to motherhood, yes to pleasure".]] On March 8, 1984 in Argentina, the first International Women's Day demonstrations since the end of the country's military regime took place in the [[Congressional Plaza]], in what is now considered a landmark.<ref name="revistafurias">{{cite web|url=http://revistafurias.com/8-de-marzo-de-1984/|language=es|title=8 de marzo de 1984|last=Bellucci|first=Mabel|publisher=Revista Furias|access-date=March 8, 2019}}</ref> The event was organized by the Multisectorial de la Mujer (English: Multisectorial of Women), an organization formed by members of women's groups, feminists, housewives and representatives of political parties and unions.<ref name="revistafurias"/> An emblematic moment of the protests was when activist [[María Elena Oddone]] climbed up the stairs of the Monument of the Two Congresses and raised a banner that read "No to motherhood, yes to pleasure". Her banner, as well as those held by other [[radical feminist]]s that day, was harshly criticized by the press for being too provocative. Oddone was also repudiated within the feminist movement. Elena Tchalidy, president of the [[Alicia Moreau de Justo]] Foundation, said: "March 8 was the first public act and she walked with [that sign]. It came out in the magazine that today would be ''Caras'' or ''Gente''. Then she said to me: 'Oh, three girls came to me.' 'Yes', I told her, 'and you distanced a few thousand.'<ref name="revistafurias"/> Oddone recalled the meeting with the Multisectorial de la Mujer that took place two days after the event in her autobiography, claiming she replied to their "lapidary critics": "I am not a feminist to please anyone but to tell the truth about our condition. I did not write those banners to be liked. If they caused scandal, it is because the truth is always scandalous. We received Dr. Justo with admiration and affection. Eighty years ago, she and her companions who asked for the right to vote were called 'crazy'. I am willing to wait the same number of years for my banners to be understood."<ref>{{cite book|last=Oddone|first=María Elena|page=34|language=es|title=La pasión por la libertad: Memorias de una feminista|year=2001|publisher=Colihue-Mimbipa|isbn=978-9992582374}}</ref>
===Adoption by United Nations===
The [[United Nations]] began celebrating International Women's Day in 1975, which had been proclaimed the [[International Women's Year]]. In 1977, the [[United Nations General Assembly]] invited member states to ''"proclaim in accordance with their historical and national traditions and customs, any day of the year as United Nations Day for Women's Rights and International Peace"''.<ref>{{UN doc |docid=A-RES-32-142 |body=A |session=32 |type=R |resolution_number=142 |title=Women's participation in the strengthening of international peace and security and in the struggle against colonialism, racism, racial discrimination, foreign aggression and occupation and all forms of foreign domination |date=16 December 1977 |accessdate=10 March 2024}} {{Dead link|date=March 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://undocs.org/en/A/RES/32/142 |title=UN Resolution A/RES/32/142 |publisher=United Nations General Assembly |access-date=10 March 2024}}</ref> In common with most countries, March 8 has been traditionally recognised as the day for International Women's Days by the UN for [[women's rights]] and [[world peace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/in-focus/international-womens-day|title=International Women's Day|publisher=United Nations|access-date=February 13, 2014|archive-date=May 12, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210512134039/https://www.unwomen.org/en/news/in-focus/international-womens-day|url-status=live}}</ref> It has since been commemorated annually by the UN and much of the world, with each year's observance centered on a particular theme or issue within women's rights.

The [[Suffrage Science award]] is a prize for women in science, engineering, and computing founded in 2011, on the 100th anniversary of International Women's Day, by the MRC London Institute of Medical Sciences (LMS).<ref>{{cite web |title=Suffrage Science |url=https://lms.mrc.ac.uk/public-engagement-2/suffrage-science/ |website=Medical Research Council – London Institute of Medical Sciences |accessdate=26 September 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=javvp1e5yt8 |title=Helen Pankhurst talks to Susan Watts about science, women and activism. |website=youtube.com |date=December 15, 2015 |accessdate=2020-11-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ZsDx70A3TU |title=Helen Pankhurst on today's inspirational activists |website=youtube.com |date=December 15, 2015 |accessdate=2020-11-08}}</ref>
===2012=== {{Commons category|International Women's Day in 2012}} [[Oxfam]] America invited people to celebrate inspiring women in their lives by sending a free International Women's Day e-Card or honoring a woman whose efforts had made a difference in the fight against hunger and poverty with Oxfam's International Women's Day award.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://actfast.oxfamamerica.org/index.php/issues/women |title=International Women's Day Celebration |publisher=Actfast.oxfamamerica.org |access-date=March 8, 2012 |archive-date=September 12, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130912231228/http://actfast.oxfamamerica.org/index.php/issues/women |url-status=dead }}</ref>
On the occasion of International Women's Day 2012, the [[International Committee of the Red Cross|ICRC]] called for more action to help the mothers and wives of people who have gone missing during armed conflict. The vast majority of people who go missing in connection with conflict are men. As well as the anguish of not knowing what has happened to the missing husband or son, many of these women face economic and practical difficulties. The ICRC underlined the duty of parties to this conflict to search for the missing and provide information to the families.<ref>[http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/news-release/2012/women-day-news-2012.htm Helping women take matters into their own hands] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311144120/http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/news-release/2012/women-day-news-2012.htm |date=March 11, 2012 }} International Committee of the Red Cross</ref>
[[Kabul]]'s first [[internet cafe]] for women, named the [[Sahar Gul]] internet cafe, was opened on International Women's Day in 2012.<ref name=BBCMar12>{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/learningenglish/language/wordsinthenews/2012/03/120312_witn_women_cafe.shtml|title=Kabul's first women-only internet cafe|publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=12 March 2012|accessdate=12 July 2013}}</ref>
On International Women's Day 2012 [[Alesha Dixon]] launched [[Avon Products|Avon]]'s Pass It On campaign to highlight domestic abuse issues in the United Kingdom by encouraging the purchase of a necklace, described by her as "a symbol of women's empowerment, and infinite possibilities for women";<ref name="PassItOn">{{cite news|author=Daniel Sperling|url= http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/news/a370014/alesha-dixon-launches-domestic-violence-campaign-talks-mums-ordeal.html|title=Alesha Dixon launches domestic violence campaign, talks mum's ordeal|work=Digital Spy |location=London |date=8 March 2012 |access-date=5 July 2012}}</ref> the proceeds from those purchases were donated to [[Refuge (United Kingdom charity)|Refuge]] and [[Women's Aid]].<ref name="PassItOn"/>
===2013=== {{Commons category|International Women's Day in 2013}} The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) drew attention to the plight of women in prison.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/news-release/2013/03-07-women-day-2013.htm |title=The forgotten plight of women behind bars |date=March 7, 2013 |publisher=ICRC |access-date=March 8, 2013 |archive-date=March 11, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311104407/http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/news-release/2013/03-07-women-day-2013.htm |url-status=live }}</ref>
It was reported the 70% of women worldwide experience some sort of physical or sexual violence in their life. Irina Bovoka, [[UNESCO]] Director General as of International Women's Day 2013, stated that in order "to empower women and ensure equality, we must challenge every form of violence every time it occurs."<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/unesco/events/prizes-and-celebrations/celebrations/international-days/international-womens-day-2013/|title=International Women's Day 2013 | United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|access-date=April 5, 2021|archive-date=May 12, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210512220302/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/unesco/events/prizes-and-celebrations/celebrations/international-days/international-womens-day-2013/|url-status=live}}</ref> In view of the increase in violence against women and following the brutal attack on [[Malala Yousafzai]] in October 2012, the UN focused their attention on ending violence against women and made this the central theme for International Women's Day 2013. UNESCO acknowledged that violence against young girls was one of the major reasons for girls not attending school and subsequently collaborated with governments around the globe to support women's rights in providing a quality education in a safe environment.<ref name="auto"/>
For a more cultural and artistic celebration, UNESCO also held a concert in Paris as a "Tribute to Women in Music: from the romantic to the electronics".<ref name="auto"/>
[[Bhagat Phool Singh Government Medical College for Women]] was inaugurated on International Women's Day 2013; it is the first women's Government Medical College of [[independent India]] and the first such institution in [[North India]] since [[Delhi]]’s [[Lady Hardinge Medical College]] that was established in 1914.<ref name="thehindu">{{cite news|title=Sonia inaugurates first all-women medical college|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/sonia-inaugurates-first-allwomen-medical-college/article4490212.ece|access-date=9 March 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=9 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Sonia Gandhi inaugurates Women Medical College in Haryana|url=http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/HAR-congress-president-and-upa-chairperson-sonia-gandhi-inaugurates-medical-college--4202206-NOR.html|access-date=9 March 2013|newspaper=Daily Bhaskar|date=9 March 2013}}</ref>
[[Bobbi Brown]] Cosmetics launched the Pretty Powerful Campaign for Women & Girls on International Women's Day in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elleuk.com/beauty/news/bobbi-brown-pretty-powerful-campaign-for-women-and-girls-international-women-s-day#image=1|title=Bobbi Brown is Pretty Powerful|last=Beresiner|first=Sophie|magazine=Elle UK|access-date= February 15, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306214619/http://www.elleuk.com/beauty/news/bobbi-brown-pretty-powerful-campaign-for-women-and-girls-international-women-s-day#image=1#image=1|archive-date=March 6, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> Pretty Powerful supports organizations that seek to empower women through job skills training programs and girls through education.<ref name="amny">{{cite web|url=http://www.amny.com/urbanite-1.812039/kkb-talk-what-beauty-means-to-an-industry-icon-1.6865217|title=What beauty means to an industry icon|publisher=AM New York|access-date= February 15, 2014|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140127003701/http://www.amny.com/urbanite-1.812039/kkb-talk-what-beauty-means-to-an-industry-icon-1.6865217|archive-date= January 27, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/beauty/2013/04/girl-power-bobbi-brown-s-pretty-powerful-campaign|title=Girl Power! Bobbi Brown's Pretty Powerful Campaign|last=Kaiser|first=Rachel|magazine=Vanity Fair|access-date= February 15, 2014}}</ref>
===2014=== [[International Women's Collaboration Brew Day]] is an annual event that takes place each year on International Women's Day since 2014,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.laweekly.com/restaurants/las-lady-brewers-releasing-beer-made-on-international-womens-collaboration-brew-day-4521797|title=L.A.'s Lady Brewers Releasing Beer Made on International Women's Collaboration Brew Day|last=Bennett|first=Sarah|date=19 March 2014|work=LA Weekly|access-date=19 November 2016}}</ref><ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.laweekly.com/restaurants/las-female-brewers-to-celebrate-international-womens-collaboration-brew-day-4495475 |title=L.A.'s Female Brewers to Celebrate International Women's Collaboration Brew Day |last=Bennett |first=Sarah |date=7 March 2014 |work=LA Weekly |access-date=19 November 2016 }} </ref> which gathers women brewers around the world who brew the same beer, with all proceeds donated to charity. The British Ambassador's residence in [[Belgrade]], “Elsie Inglis House”, is named after [[Elsie Inglis]], a doctor and campaigner for women's suffrage and founder of the Scottish Women's Hospitals in Serbia. The renaming ceremony took place on International Women's Day in 2015 and was conducted by the President of Serbia [[Tomislav Nikolić|Tomislav Nikolic]] and then UK Ambassador [[Denis Keefe]].<ref>{{cite web |title=British Residence in Belgrade named after Elsie Inglis |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/british-residence-in-belgrade-named-after-elsie-inglis |website=Gov.UK |access-date=6 January 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Serbia honours life of war doctor Elsie Inglis|url=http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/news/serbia-honours-life-of-war-doctor-elsie-inglis-1-3719756|access-date=17 March 2015|work=Edinburgh Evening News|date=17 March 2015}}</ref>
[[The Female Lead]] is an educational charity launched on International Women's Day 2015 in the United Kingdom, dedicated to increasing the visibility of women's success stories in all walks of life and offering girls a wider selection of role models than those represented in popular culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.shoutoutuk.org/2018/06/14/why-everyone-is-talking-about-the-female-lead-an-interview-with-edwina-dunn/|title=Why Everyone is Talking About The Female Lead: An Interview with Edwina Dunn|date=2018-06-14|website=Shout Out UK|language=en-GB|access-date=2019-11-25|archive-date=February 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210213155217/https://www.shoutoutuk.org/2018/06/14/why-everyone-is-talking-about-the-female-lead-an-interview-with-edwina-dunn/|url-status=dead}}</ref> It was founded by data science entrepreneur [[Edwina Dunn]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stylist.co.uk/visible-women/edwina-dunn-the-female-lead-book-stem-future-finder-schools-tesco/237412|title=Woman of the Week: Edwina Dunn, The Female Lead founder|last=Crockett|first=Moya|date=2018-11-12|website=Stylist|language=en|access-date=2019-11-24}}</ref>

===2016=== {{Commons category|International Women's Day in 2016}} On International Women's Day 2016, [[One Campaign]] relaunched their Poverty is Sexist campaign, featuring an updated report including new figures, such as the fact that as of 2016 half a billion women still cannot read and that girls account for 74% of all new HIV infections among adolescents across Africa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/meryl-streep-amy-poehler-and-elton-john-pen-letter-to-world-lead/|title=Meryl Streep, Amy Poehler and Elton John pen letter to world leaders to 'end gender inequality'|website=The Telegraph|date=March 8, 2016 |access-date=2016-03-17}}</ref>
The President of India, [[Pranab Mukherjee|Shri Pranab Mukherjee]], said: "On the occasion of International Women's Day, I extend warm greetings and good wishes to the women of India and thank them for their contributions over the years in the building of our nation."<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Business Standard India|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/government-press-release/president-of-indias-message-on-the-eve-of-international-womens-day-116030700685_1.html|title=President of Indias message on the eve of International Women's Day|location=[[Delhi]]|date=March 7, 2016|access-date=March 7, 2016|archive-date=March 8, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308002240/http://www.business-standard.com/article/government-press-release/president-of-indias-message-on-the-eve-of-international-womens-day-116030700685_1.html|url-status=live}}</ref> The ministry of women and child development announced the setting up of four more one-stop crisis centers on March 8, in addition to the eight already functioning across the country.<ref>{{cite web|website=[[The Times of India]]|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Womens-Day-gift-Govt-to-come-with-4-one-stop-crisis-centres/articleshow/51283838.cms|title=Women's Day gift: Govt to come with 4 one-stop crisis centres|date=March 7, 2016|access-date=March 7, 2016|archive-date=August 29, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160829010431/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Womens-Day-gift-Govt-to-come-with-4-one-stop-crisis-centres/articleshow/51283838.cms|url-status=live}}</ref> Ahead of Women's Day, the national carrier Air India operated what it claimed to be the world's longest non-stop flight where the entire flight operations were handled by women, as part of International Women's Day celebrations. The flight, from Delhi to San Francisco, covered a distance of around 14,500 kilometers in around 17 hours.<ref>{{cite web|website=[[The Indian Express]]|title=Ahead of Women's Day, Air India operates 'world's longest all-women flight'|author=PTI|date=March 7, 2016|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/ahead-of-womens-day-air-india-operates-worlds-longest-all-women-flight/|access-date=March 7, 2016|archive-date=March 8, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308114336/http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/ahead-of-womens-day-air-india-operates-worlds-longest-all-women-flight/|url-status=live}}</ref>
While speaking at an International Women's Day 2016 event in India, [[Kanhaiya Kumar]] referred to the [[Human rights abuses in Jammu and Kashmir|rape of Kashmiri women]] committed by personnel of the Indian Army. This was criticized as being "anti-national" by the [[Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha]] (BJYM). The BJYM filed a complaint against Kumar and JNU professor [[Nivedita Menon]], alleging them of making "anti-national" statements.<ref>{{Cite news|date=9 March 2016|title=Kanhaiya in a fresh spot over "anti-national" remarks|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/kanhaiya-in-a-fresh-spot-over-anti-national-remarks-116030901337_1.html|work=Business Standard|agency=Press Trust of India}}</ref> A sedition and defamation case was filed against Kumar in a civil court in Patna.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Sedition case against JNUSU president Kanhaiya Kumar in Patna court | Patna News – Times of India|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/Sedition-case-against-JNUSU-president-Kanhaiya-Kumar-in-Patna-court/articleshow/51359589.cms|website=The Times of India|date=March 11, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|date=11 March 2016|title=BJP 'worker' files complaint against Kanhaiya Kumar in UP|url=https://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/bjp-worker-files-complaint-against-kanhaiya-kumar-in-up-116031100968_1.html|work=Business Standard|agency=Press Trust of India}}</ref> Also, on 10 March 2016, Kumar was manhandled and abused on the JNU campus by a man who accused him of being a ''deshdrohi'' ({{Translation|traitor to the nation}}). ===2017=== {{Commons category|International Women's Day in 2017}} In a message in support of International Women's Day, the UN Secretary-General [[António Guterres]] commented on how [[women's rights]] were being "reduced, restricted and reversed". With men still in leadership positions and a widening economic [[Gender pay gap|gender gap]], he called for change "by empowering women at all levels, enabling their voices to be heard and giving them control over their own lives and over the future of our world".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2017/3/statement-sg-international-womens-day-2017|title=UN Secretary-General's Message for International Women's Day|date=March 6, 2017|publisher=UN|access-date=March 8, 2017|archive-date=March 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170307003402/http://www.unwomen.org/en/news/stories/2017/3/statement-sg-international-womens-day-2017|url-status=live}}</ref>
The first [[Jakarta]] Women's March was held on March 4, 2017 in commemoration of International Women's Day on March 8 and the [[2017 Women's March]] movement in the [[United States]].<ref name=":Jakarta19">{{Cite web|title=Women's March Jakarta 2017 to raise gender equality issues|url=https://www.thejakartapost.com/life/2017/03/03/womens-march-jakarta-2017-to-raise-gender-equality-issues.html|access-date=2020-10-19|website=The Jakarta Post|language=en}}</ref> The march was held in front of the [[Istana Negara (Jakarta)|State Palace]] in which organizers of the event delivered eight demands to the government which included: tolerance, diversity and health rights for women, elimination of violence against women, protecting the living environment and female workers, improving representation of women in the political scene, and eliminating discrimination and violence against the [[LGBT community]].<ref name=":Jakarta19"/> The 2017 Women's March was sponsored by 33 different organizations.<ref name=":Jakarta19"/><ref>{{Cite web|title=The many voices of Women's March Jakarta 2017|url=https://www.thejakartapost.com/life/2017/03/06/the-many-voices-of-womens-march-jakarta-2017.html|access-date=2020-10-19|website=The Jakarta Post|language=en}}</ref>
The SahibaSisters Foundation, Tanzania's first feminist activist institute, was founded on International Women's Day 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wluml.org/node/3513|title=Tanzania: First Feminist Activist Institute opens in Tanzania – Women Reclaiming and Redefining Cultures|author=|date=|website=www.wluml.org|accessdate=11 November 2017|archive-date=September 5, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190905174007/http://www.wluml.org/node/3513|url-status=dead}}</ref>
In Turkey, a mob illegally entered the [[Istanbul Bilgi University]] campus on International Women’s Day and attacked students celebrating the day.<ref>{{cite news|title=Group attacks Women's Day demo at Istanbul Bilgi University|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/group-attacks-womens-day-demo-at-istanbul-bilgi-university.aspx?PageID=238&NID=110587&NewsCatID=509|newspaper=Hürriyet Daily News|date=8 March 2017}}</ref>
On International Women's Day 2017, the Venezuelan national government transferred the symbolic remains of [[Apacuana]], along with those of the African slaves Hipólita and Matea, to the [[National Pantheon of Venezuela]], where the main figures of the country's history rest.<ref name="runrun">{{cite web|url=https://runrun.es/nacional/300018/trasladan-al-panteon-nacional-restos-de-la-negra-hipolita-matea-y-apacuana/|work=[[Runrunes]]|title=Trasladan al Panteón Nacional restos de la Negra Hipólita, Matea y Apacuana|date=March 8, 2017|language=es|accessdate=February 5, 2022}}</ref><ref name="estimulo">{{cite web|url=https://elestimulo.com/restos-de-hipolita-y-matea-seran-trasladados-al-panteon-nacional/|title=Restos de Hipólita y Matea serán trasladados al Panteón Nacional|date=March 1, 2017|language=es|accessdate=February 5, 2022|work=El Estímulo|location=Caracas}}</ref>
===2018=== {{See also|International Women's Strike 2018|2018 Spanish women's strike}} [[File:2018ko martxoak 8, greba feminista Iruñean - Goizeko irudiak 18.jpg|thumb|8M 2018 in [[Pamplona]]]]
Global marches and online campaigns such as #[[MeToo]] and #[[TimesUp]], which originated in the United States but became popular globally, allowed many women from different parts of the world to confront injustice and speak out on issues such as [[sexual harassment]] and assault and the [[gender pay gap]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unwomen.org/en/news/in-focus/international-womens-day/2018|title=International Women's Day 2018|access-date=April 5, 2021|archive-date=March 8, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210308120525/https://www.unwomen.org/en/news/in-focus/international-womens-day/2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
[[International Women's Strike]], also known as Paro Internacional de Mujeres, was a global movement coordinated across over 50 countries on International Women's Day, in 2017 and 2018. The [[Sex/Work Strike]] began in 2018 as part of the International Women's Strike on International Women's Day with the aim of [[decriminalization of sex work]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Blake |first1=Matt |title=Why British Sex Workers Are Striking This Friday |url=https://www.vice.com/en/article/59xqp5/why-british-sex-workers-are-striking-this-friday |website=VICE|date=March 6, 2019 }}</ref> Participants that year included the writer Molly Smith, an author of ''[[Revolting Prostitutes]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ava |first1=Caradonna |title=On International Women's Day, sex workers are going on strike |url=https://www.redpepper.org.uk/on-international-womens-day-sex-workers-are-going-on-strike |website=Red Pepper}}</ref>
In downtown [[Pristina]], [[Kosovo]], on International Women's Day 2018, three billboards were put up to protest the death of two women as a result of domestic violence.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://prishtinainsight.com/three-billboards-prishtina-kosovo-protest-domestic-violence| title=Three billboards in Prishtina, Kosovo to protest domestic violence| website=Prishtina Insight| date=March 8, 2018| access-date=March 8, 2018}}</ref>
[[Women Democratic Front]] (WDF), an independent [[socialist]]-[[feminist]] organization based and founded in [[Pakistan]], was founded on International Women's Day 2018,<ref>{{cite news |title=Reflection of increasing awareness, acceptance of women's rights |url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/290051-reflection-of-increasing-awareness-acceptance-of-women-s-rights |work=www.thenews.com.pk |language=en}}</ref> by hundreds of delegates from [[Balochistan]], [[Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], and [[Sindh]].<ref name="first">{{cite news |title=Women's Democratic Front launched to build a vibrant, socialist and a feminist movement |url=https://dailytimes.com.pk/212473/womens-democratic-front-launched-to-build-a-vibrant-socialist-and-a-feminist-movement/ |work=Daily Times |date=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Ali |first1=Hasan |title=Pakistani Women Are Leading the Struggle for Human Rights |url=https://www.thenation.com/article/world/pakistan-women-human-rights/ |date=28 September 2021}}</ref> WDF aims to unite women across the country to build a socialist feminist movement to transform the International Women's Day celebration in Pakistan into real means of action.<ref name="first" /> The manifesto and constitution of WDF opposes capitalism, patriarchy, religious fascism, national oppression and Pakistan's political system.<ref name="www.pakistantoday.com.pk">{{cite news |title=WDF demands to repeal ban on media coverage of KP's girls' schools {{!}} Pakistan Today |url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2018/10/30/wdf-demands-to-repeal-ban-on-media-coverage-of-kps-girls-schools/ |work=www.pakistantoday.com.pk}}</ref>
In 2018 and again in 2019, [[McDonald's]] turned [[Golden Arches|its arches]] upside down on its social media accounts in celebration of International Women's Day, changing the "M" to a "W." A McDonald's franchise operated by Patricial Williams in [[Lynwood, California]], also flipped the arches on its sign.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/mcdonalds-flips-arches-international-womens-day-2019-3|title=McDonald's is flipping its iconic arches upside down again for International Women's Day|author=Kate Taylor|website=[[Business Insider]]|date=March 9, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/07/mcdonalds-is-turning-its-golden-arches-upside-down.html|title=McDonald's is turning its golden arches upside down to make a statement|author=Abigail Hess|website=[[CNBC]]|date=March 7, 2018}}</ref> This prompted a mild backlash, with some arguing that the move was hypocritical due to the chain's underpaying of employees, and others observing that the "M" in the logo could just as easily stand for "men" as it could for "McDonald's."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2018/03/08/mcdonalds-international-womens-day-inverted-arches-backlash/|title=Why McDonald's International Women's Day Celebration Isn't Going as Planned|author=Natasha Bach|website=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date=March 7, 2018}}</ref>
''[[Overlooked (obituary feature)|Overlooked No More]]'' is a recurring feature in the [[obituary]] section of ''[[The New York Times]]'', which honors "remarkable people" whose deaths had been overlooked by editors of that section since its creation in 1851. The feature was introduced on March 8, 2018 for International Women's Day, where the ''Times'' published fifteen obituaries of such "overlooked" women, and has since become a weekly feature in the paper. The project was created by [[Amisha Padnani]], the digital editor of the obituaries desk,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/08/insider/overlooked-obituary.html|title=How an Obits Project on Overlooked Women Was Born|last=Padnani|first=Amisha|date=2018-03-08|work=The New York Times|access-date=2019-01-03|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> and [[Jessica Bennett (journalist)|Jessica Bennett]], the paper's gender editor. In its introduction, it was admitted that the paper's obituaries had been "dominated by white men", and that the project was intended to help "address these inequities of our time".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/13/reader-center/jessica-bennett-our-new-gender-editor-answers-your-questions.html|title=Jessica Bennett, Our New Gender Editor, Answers Your Questions|date=2017-12-13|work=The New York Times|access-date=2019-01-03|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instyle.com/news/international-womens-day-2018-new-york-times-obituaries|title=The New York Times Is Writing Obituaries for the Historical Women They Ignored|website=InStyle.com|language=en|access-date=2019-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/stevens/ct-life-stevens-thursday-nyt-female-obits-0308-story.html|title=NYT runs obits for 'overlooked' women on International Women's Day|last=Stevens|first=Heidi|website=Chicago Tribune|language=en-US|access-date=2019-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/new-york-times-overlooked-obituaries-ida-b-wells-caitlin-dickerson/|title="We want to address these inequities of our time": NYT starts new series featuring overlooked obituaries|website=www.cbsnews.com|date=March 8, 2018 |language=en-US|access-date=2019-01-03}}</ref>
===2019=== [[File:Antimonumenta 01.jpg|thumb|right|[[Antimonumenta (Mexico City)|An Antimonumenta]], installed in Mexico City on International Women's Day 2019, as photographed the day after. The circle part says "In Mexico 9 women are murdered daily" and the cross part says "Not one more!" On the opposite side, the Antimonumenta reads "We demand a national gender alert", and in the central part "No + [[Femicide]]s".]]
The federal state of Berlin marked International Women's Day as a public holiday for the first time in 2019, with parliament having approved that in January of that year. Berlin was the first German state to make International Women's Day a public holiday.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2019/03/08/701408274/berlin-marks-international-womens-day-as-a-public-holiday-for-the-first-time|title=Berlin Marks International Women's Day as a Public Holiday for the First Time|date=8 March 2019|first=James|last=Doubek|website=NPR}}</ref>
In [[Tehran]], Iran on International Women's Day 2019, groups of women appeared unveiled and protested the oppression of women. A video showed two unveiled women holding a red sign, which read "International Women's Day is a promise of a just world for all of humanity", on [[Valiasr Street]]. Another video showed a group of unveiled women on a [[Tehran Metro]] car handing out flowers to passengers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/activists-appear-unveiled-in-tehran-on-women-s-day-/4821178.html|title=Activists Appear Unveiled in Tehran on Women's Day|website=VOA|date=March 8, 2019 |access-date=14 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190401101955/https://www.voanews.com/a/activists-appear-unveiled-in-tehran-on-women-s-day-/4821178.html|archive-date=1 April 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>
[[Antimonumenta (Mexico City)|An Antimonumenta]] was erected on 8 March 2019 on [[Avenida Juárez|Juárez Avenue]], in front of the [[Palacio de Bellas Artes|Palace of Fine Arts]] in Mexico City, during the annual Mexican International Women's Day march of women protesting against [[Violence against women in Mexico|gender violence]]. The installation of the structure lasted more than two hours, and it was paid for by relatives of victims of [[femicide]], [[feminist]] collectives and civil society organizations.<ref name=local>{{cite web|url=https://local.mx/ciudad-de-mexico/antimonumenta/|title=La Antimonumenta: la escultura más importante para no olvidar|trans-title=The Antimonumenta: the most important sculpture to not forget|date=5 March 2020|first=Ana|last=Buerón|work=Local.mx|access-date=13 December 2021|language=es}}</ref> According to activists: "This anti-monument is to remind us that there is still no justice for women in Mexico, that we continue disappearing and that we continue being killed. We will not remain silent". Original text in Spanish: "{{lang|es|Este antimonumento es para recordar que sigue sin haber justicia para las mujeres en México, que seguimos desapareciendo y que nos siguen matando. No nos vamos a callar}}".<ref>{{Cite news|last=Gómez|first=Nancy|date=8 March 2019|title=Marcha #8M2019; instalan antimonumenta por feminicidios|language=es|trans-title=March #8M2019; anti-monument for femicides installed|work=SDP Noticias|url=https://www.sdpnoticias.com/nacional/antimonumenta-feminicidios-instalan-8m2019-marcha.html|access-date=13 December 2021}}</ref>
On International Women's Day 2019, the [[Burning Sun scandal]] led to a street protest in [[Gangnam District|Gangnam]], South Korea against the Burning Sun and other nightclubs, calling for an end to what the protesters called a culture that treats women as sexual objects.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kim|first=Dae-young|title="클럽 내 강간문화 근절하라"...강남 한복판서 '클럽시위'|url=https://www.msn.com/ko-kr/news/politics/%E2%80%9C%ED%81%B4%EB%9F%BD-%EB%82%B4-%EA%B0%95%EA%B0%84%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EA%B7%BC%EC%A0%88%ED%95%98%EB%9D%BC%E2%80%9D%EA%B0%95%EB%82%A8-%ED%95%9C%EB%B3%B5%ED%8C%90%EC%84%9C-%ED%81%B4%EB%9F%BD%EC%8B%9C%EC%9C%84/ar-BBUxOvh|date=March 9, 2019|work=[[MSN]]|language=ko|access-date=March 23, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190328165305/https://www.msn.com/ko-kr/news/politics/%E2%80%9C%ED%81%B4%EB%9F%BD-%EB%82%B4-%EA%B0%95%EA%B0%84%EB%AC%B8%ED%99%94-%EA%B7%BC%EC%A0%88%ED%95%98%EB%9D%BC%E2%80%9D%EA%B0%95%EB%82%A8-%ED%95%9C%EB%B3%B5%ED%8C%90%EC%84%9C-%ED%81%B4%EB%9F%BD%EC%8B%9C%EC%9C%84/ar-BBUxOvh|archive-date=March 28, 2019}}</ref><ref name="ignited">{{cite web|last=Sam Kim and Jihye Lee|title=The Sex Scandal Engulfing K-Pop|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-15/sex-scandal-engulfs-k-pop-tarnishing-industry-s-image|date=March 15, 2019|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|access-date=March 20, 2019|archive-date=March 20, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190320205107/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-15/sex-scandal-engulfs-k-pop-tarnishing-industry-s-image|url-status=live}}</ref>
===2020=== [[File:Reivindicaciones 8M (49638492866).jpg|thumb|8M 2020 in Spain]]
Despite the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], street marches occurred in London, Paris, Madrid, Brussels, Moscow and other European cities.<ref name="BBC">{{cite web |title=International Women's Day: Marchers around the world call for equality |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-51791335 |website=BBC News |date=March 8, 2020 |access-date=March 8, 2020 |archive-date=March 8, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200308180237/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-51791335 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Thousands March in Spain on Women's Day Despite Coronavirus Fears |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2020-03-08/thousands-march-in-spain-on-womens-day-despite-coronavirus-fears |date=March 8, 2020 |work=[[US News]] |agency=[[Reuters]] |access-date=April 14, 2020 |archive-date=April 12, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200412025031/https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2020-03-08/thousands-march-in-spain-on-womens-day-despite-coronavirus-fears |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=International Women's Day Marked Across the World |url=https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/international-womens-day-marked-across-world |work=VOA News |date=March 8, 2020 |access-date=April 14, 2020 |archive-date=March 9, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200309200331/https://www.voanews.com/east-asia-pacific/international-womens-day-marked-across-world |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=International Women's Day 2020 around the world – in pictures |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2020/mar/08/international-womens-day-2020-around-the-world-in-pictures |work=The Guardian |date=March 8, 2020 |access-date=April 14, 2020 |archive-date=March 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200329011105/https://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2020/mar/08/international-womens-day-2020-around-the-world-in-pictures |url-status=live }}</ref>
The [[Aurat March#2020 march|Aurat March]] in [[Islamabad]] was marred by attacks from stone throwers, after a failed attempt to have it banned as un-[[Islam]]ic.
In [[Bishkek]], the capital of [[Kyrgyzstan]], police detained dozens of marchers shortly after masked men reportedly attacked the march.<ref name="BBC"/>
In 2020, the coalition sponsoring the [[Jakarta]] Women's March expanded to over 60 civil rights organizations under [[Gerak Perempuan]] (the Women's Movement against Violence alliance).<ref name="Jakarta:20">{{Cite web|title=Activists to protest systematic violence against women on Women's March|url=https://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2020/03/06/activists-to-protest-systematic-violence-against-women-on-womens-march.html|access-date=2020-10-19|website=The Jakarta Post|language=en}}</ref> The march was held at the same time of year as the first event in 2017 and held in conjunction with International Women's Day.<ref name="Jakarta:20" /> Protestors took to the streets to demand that the government put a stop to systematic violence against women and pass the sexual assault eradication bill.<ref name="Jakarta:21">{{Cite web|title=Hundreds rally in Jakarta to protest violence against women on International Women's Day|url=https://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2020/03/08/hundreds-rally-in-jakarta-to-protest-violence-against-women-on-international-womens-day.html|access-date=2020-10-19|website=The Jakarta Post|language=en}}</ref> The demands of the coalition included the establishment of a system of laws that protect women and the abolishment of discriminatory regulations.<ref name="Jakarta:21" /><ref name="Jakarta:20" />
Mexico saw women [[Violence against women in Mexico#Un Día Sin Mujeres protest|take to the streets on International Women's Day 2020]] to demand that the government be held accountable for their inability to acknowledge gender violence as an issue. They demanded that murderers be held accountable for their crimes, and that awareness be brought to the sexual and physical harassment experienced by women daily. On the day of the protest, an estimated 80,000 people took part in Mexico City.<ref>{{Cite news |date=9 March 2020 |title=Mexican women strike to protest against gender-based violence |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-51811040}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.globalcitizen.org/de/content/ni-una-mas-the-mexican-epidemic-of-femicide/|title=Femicides in Mexico Are on the Rise ¡Ni Una Mas!}}</ref> The following day, ''Brujas del Mar'', a group of women from Veracruz led the charge of another protest. On March 9, the protest was dubbed "Un Día Sin Mujeres" (A Day Without Women). The aim of this subsequent protest was to simulate a world in which women did not exist. The protest encouraged women to stay home and withdraw from activities that they would normally be involved in. Women stayed home from work, school, social media and refrained from making online purchases.<ref>{{Cite web |date=10 March 2020 |title=In Mexico City, a "Day Without Women" |url=https://www.vogue.com/article/mexico-city-day-without-women}}</ref>
[[Witches of Scotland]] was a campaign launched on International Women's Day in 2020, led by [[Claire Mitchell]] QC and writer [[Zoe Venditozzi]], seeking legal [[pardon]]s and justice for the people, primarily women, convicted of [[witchcraft]] and executed in [[Scotland]] between 1563 and 1736. A pardon and an apology was made on International Women's Day 2022.<ref name="Witches:0">{{Cite web |date=2021-03-18 |title=PE01855: Pardon and memorialise those convicted under the Witchcraft Act 1563 |url=https://external.parliament.scot/GettingInvolved/Petitions/witchesofscotland |access-date=2021-10-25 |website=external.parliament.scot |archive-date=October 25, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211025160613/https://external.parliament.scot/GettingInvolved/Petitions/witchesofscotland |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref name="Witches:1">{{Cite web |title=About |url=https://www.witchesofscotland.com/about |access-date=2021-10-25 |website=Witches Of Scotland |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Survey of Scottish Witchcraft – Introduction to Scottish Witchcraft |url=https://www.shca.ed.ac.uk/Research/witches//introduction.html |access-date=2022-07-08 |website=www.shca.ed.ac.uk}}</ref>
The [[Women's Party (South Korea)|Women's Party]] ([[Korean language|Korean]]: 여성의당), a South Korean [[Single-issue politics|single-issue political party]], was founded on International Women's Day 2020 and advocates for [[feminism]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.womennews.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=196256|title=한국 최초 여성주의 정당 '여성의당' 창당 본격화… "여성에 대한 모든 혐오 반대"|date=2020-02-15|website=여성신문|language=ko|access-date=2020-04-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=South Korea's new feminist party aims to shake up patriarchal nation|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/South-Korea-s-new-feminist-party-aims-to-shake-up-patriarchal-nation|access-date=2020-11-22|website=Nikkei Asia|language=en-GB}}</ref> The party calls for greater representation of women and equality in politics and an end to all forms of violence, discrimination and inequality against women in the workplace.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.womennews.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=196241|title="남성 중심 정치에 반대합니다"… '여성의당' 15일 발기인대회 [발기취지문 전문]|date=2020-02-14|website=여성신문|language=ko|access-date=2020-04-24}}</ref>

===2021=== {{Commons category|International Women's Day in 2021}}
On International Women's Day 2021, politician [[Dave Sharma]] of Australia was criticized for handing out flowers to women while the [[Morrison Government]] faced ongoing scrutiny over how it had handled [[2021 Australian Parliament House sexual misconduct allegations|allegations of rape and sexual misconduct by government ministers and staffers]]. The gesture was seen by some as "failing to read the room", and was held up as evidence of the government being out of touch on women's rights issues.<ref>{{cite web|date=8 March 2021|title=Liberal MP Dave Sharma marks International Women's Day by giving flowers to female commuters|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/mar/08/liberal-mp-dave-sharma-marks-international-womens-day-by-giving-flowers-to-female-commuters|access-date=5 April 2021|website=The Guardian}}</ref>
In [[Guatemala City]] a thousand women and men marched demanding an end to violence against women on International Women's Day 2021.<ref name="auto6">{{cite news |title=Movilización masiva en El Salvador en favor de despenalizar el aborto |url=https://www.jornada.com.mx/notas/2021/03/08/mundo/movilizacion-masiva-en-el-salvador-en-favor-de-despenalizar-el-aborto/ |access-date=March 8, 2021 |work=jornada.com.mx |publisher=La Jornada |date=March 8, 2021 |language=es}}</ref>
[[Antimonumenta (Morelia)|An Antimonumenta]] was installed next to the [[Fuente de las Tarascas]], along {{ill|Avenida Francisco I. Madero (Morelia)|lt=Francisco I. Madero Avenue|es|Avenida Francisco I. Madero (Morelia)}} in [[Morelia]], [[Michoacán]], Mexico, on International Women's Day 2021, during the annual Mexican march of women protesting against [[Violence against women in Mexico|gender violence]]. The sculpture, symbolically named [[Antimonumenta]], was inspired by other similar [[Anti-monuments in Mexico|anti-monuments]] like [[Antimonumenta (Mexico City)|the one in Mexico City]]. The erection of an antimonumenta symbolizes the demand for justice for women who suffer from violence in the country.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.revistadelauniversidad.mx/articles/8fd237c9-66e0-467c-9d72-f9028779935a/arrebatar-las-narrativas |title=Arrebatar las narrativas |first=Irene |last=Tello Arista |date=May 2021 |language=es |trans-title=To snatch the narratives |work=Revista de la Universidad de México |access-date=3 January 2021}}</ref> The original work was destroyed a few hours after its installation, but a replica was installed the following month.<ref name="franco2021">{{cite web |url=https://www.elsoldemexico.com.mx/republica/sociedad/feministas-de-michoacan-reinstalan-antimonumenta-en-morelia-6639651.html |title=Feministas de Michoacán reinstalan Antimonumenta en Morelia |work=El Sol de Morelia |first=Paola |last=Franco |date=25 April 2021 |language=es |access-date=30 December 2021 |trans-title=Michoacán feminists reinstall Antimonumenta in Morelia}}</ref> The original Antimonumenta was painted completely in purple and it was represented with a symbol of the feminist struggle, which is based on the [[Planet symbols|symbol of Venus]] with a raised fist in the center. In feminism, the color purple often represents "loyalty, constancy towards a purpose [and] unwavering firmness towards a cause".<ref name=monitor>{{cite web |url=https://www.monitorexpresso.com/ni-un-dia-duro-la-antimonumenta-en-morelia-michoacan/ |title=Ni un día duró la antimonumenta en Morelia, Michoacán |location=Michoacán |work=Monitor Expresso |date=9 March 2021 |first=Celic |last=Mendoza |access-date=30 December 2021 |trans-title=Antimonumenta did not even last a day in Morelia, Michoacán}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=García |first=Paula |date=6 March 2019 |title=Este es el origen de los símbolos feministas |language=es |access-date=13 December 2021 |trans-title=This is the origin of the feminist symbols |url=https://hipertextual.com/2019/03/es-origen-simbolos-feministas|url-status=live |website=Hipertextual|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190306181647/https://hipertextual.com/2019/03/es-origen-simbolos-feministas |archive-date=6 March 2019}}</ref> The Antimonumenta was a metal sculpture whose upper part had, written in Spanish, in violet capital letters: "Alive, free and happy", while on the arm of the cross it was written, "Not one more!".<ref name=monitor/> On the opposite side, the Antimonumenta had written the same phrases.
